Basic Built-in Functions.val: Reads a line from input, converts it to a string and returns that
Returns the length (the number of items) of an object
Returns the largest item in the list or the largest of the two or more arguments
Returns the smallest item in the list or the smallest of the two or more arguments
Returns first argument to the power second argument
Returns a list of integers starting from start and ending at stop (exclusive), having a difference of step between any two adjacent elements
Similar to range(), but returns an xrange iterator object instead of a list
Converts an integer number to a binary string
Converts an integer number to an octal string
Converts an integer nuber to a lowercase hexadecimal string prefixed with '0x'
Returns an integer object from a number or string
Returns a floating point number from a number or string
Returns the type of any object

String Methods.val: Returns a string in all uppercase
Returns a string in all lowercase
Returns a string with first character capitalized, the rest lower
Returns a string with the leading and trailing whitespace removed
Returns a string with the leading whitespace removed
Returns a string with the trailing whitespace removed
Returns the number of occurrences of item
Replaces all occurrences of old substring with new
Returns a string centered in a field of width spaces
Returns a string left justified in a field of width spaces
Returns a string right justified in a field of width spaces
Returns the leftmost index where the substring item is found
Returns the rightmost index where the substring item is found
Similar to find() except causes a runtime error if item is not found
Similar to rfind() except causes a runtime error if item is not found
Returns a string of one character whose ASCII code is the integer passed as argument
Returns an integer representing the Unicode code point of any string of one character

List (Array) Methods.val: Adds an item to the end of the list
Extends the list by appending all the items in the given list
Inserts an item at a given position
Removes the first item from the list with aforementioned parameter value
Removes the item at the given position in the list, and return it
Returns the index in the list
Returns the number of times that appears in the list.
Sorts the items of the list in place
Sorts the items of the list in place, in descending order
Reverses the elements of the list, in place
Returns the total sum of all items of the list
Concatenates all the items of the list

Dictionary Methods.val: Returns a shallow copy of dictionary

File Methods and Constants.val: Opens a file, returning an object of the file type
Closes the file; a closed file cannot be read or written any more
Returns the integer “file descriptor” that is used by the underlying implementation to request I/O operations from the operating system
Writes a string to the file
Writes a sequence of strings to the file
Bool indicating the current state of the file object
The encoding that this file uses
The Unicode error handler used along with the encoding
The I/O mode for the file

Date and Time Methods.val: Gives new values by whichever keyword arguments are specified
Returns the proleptic Gregorian ordinal of the date, where January 1 of year 1 has ordinal 1
Returns the day of the week as an integer, where Monday is 0 and Sunday is 6
Returns the day of the week as an integer, where Monday is 1 and Sunday is 7
Returns a 3-tuple, (ISO year, ISO week number, ISO weekday)
Returns a string representing the date in ISO 8601 format, "YYYY-MM-DD"
For a date d, str(d) is equivalent to d.isoformat()
Returns a string representing the date
Returns a string representing the date, controlled by an explicit format string
Same as date.strftime(). This makes it possible to specify format string for a date object when using str.format()

Math Functions and Constants.val: Returns the absolute value of a number
Returns factorial of the argument value
Returns the floating point value number to the given number of digits after the decimal point
Returns the argument raised to a power (e**x)
Returns first parameter raised to the power by second parameter
